weird technology company which is probably very similar to what many of you in this room might as well and we

active customers today we see that many of these organizations are actually digital businesses themselves and let me

and they actually going into into various other directions as well and clearly they're very digital business

however we look at these organizations we actually see that there are also

service in the UK which is the broker between universities and colleges and higher education providers in the
students applying for work spaces we've got the European Space Agency is one of
our customers we've got NASA Transport for London serving 30 million journeys a day but all these organizations whatever

of their digital assets to their customers through applications such as journey planner which allow their
customers in real time to plan their journeys around London and that may
include using the London Underground it may include using bus services for instance taxi services bicycles for hire
and various other services which are available as well so such businesses even though they have physical assets
they still need to expose digital assets and that's how they provide additional services an additional value to their
customers so they happen also to be digital businesses so what does it
actually mean to be a digital business from our perspective a digital business
is a business which is capable of identifying and in creating a catalogue
of their assets which are very much likely to be digital assets again and turning these assets by deriving
intelligence from these assets into business value and that's really the idea of digital businesses today and how
do you think that these businesses able to accomplish such a such transformation
and then be able to derive even more customer value well clearly they have to use software for us that software is
very much likely to come in the form of services although clearly some some organizations would still be
tempted to buy licenses as well so from our perspective at the digital business
is an organization that can change their business models from traditional
business models which which are based on traditional assets which sometimes maybe less digital in nature into assets which
derive for a lot of information and collect a lot of information about their interactions with customers and they can
derive additional intelligence from that information and turn it into their competitive advantage so we see that
digital businesses actually create codes which transforms the data into
intelligence and without in mind if we look at the rules of x which digital
businesses need to abide perhaps our rule number one has to be that a digital
organization has to build their success and their business models by using data
assets that they have in place and implementing code that transforms these data assets into intelligence so how
about hardware is how do I going to be important in such an equation we said
the software is going to be used to transform the information and most of the time we are probably going to see
that in a cloud-based environment such organizations are not going to be limited by how much they can spend on

necessarily spending millions on data centers on software on storage on

momentum and how much spending power is an organization you have suddenly a

themselves on the basis of the ideas that they have the way they implement

relationships that they establish as well and therefore they're going to
become disruptive in three different ways first of all it is going to be very
important how fast they can take these ideas to market you card with an idea can you actually test that idea today or
is it going to take you two years to test this idea secondly your disruption
is going to be to depend on how well you can collect analyze disseminate it and
store information that you are generating from these ideas and thirdly
you're going to depend on customer feedback is you implement your ideas you

that we always start with a customer so everything that we implement starts with how is it going to benefit the customer

bottlenecks that we often come across some of red and add some monoliths throughout the years and I personally

by building clutch monolithic applications that consists of millions
of lines of code that consists of a huge functional specification that probably
has a hundreds or even perhaps 10,000 with and more features in it but there
is a single big monolithic application that implements this piece of
functionality you've probably seen many of these applications you've probably seen operating systems that take three
four five years to take to market you've probably seen your favorites erp vanda
take many years to release the next version of your erp products that's the

organization but well already in a good position to break away from the mama
lift but we were all back into 2009 and one which is when we started on this
digital transformation journey we had a single big monolithic application which
was the amazon.com websites it was huge there were thousands of developers
working on a single deliverable a single executable website which was our face to
the world and it wasn't dynamic at all and if you look at such a more hritik product which is what is happening this
many developers working many many days months sometimes years to release the
whole product and then there is the delivery pipeline and all of these people need to get together they need to
commit their codes they need to link it imagine what happens if someone wants to use a different version of the library
and you've got a few thousand developers and how you convince everyone else that you need to use a different version of
the library imagine that someone wants to implement a very small change even a bug fixing in their environment and they
have to wait for let's say three months until the next a time when we link all
of these different deliverables together and compare them and release them into production so a monolith is your
monolithic system as such it's probably going to lead you in the direction whereby you got very long cycles and you
have to synchronize a lot between various different teams in order to release it in yes that's still the way
software and systems are being implemented unfortunately now we kind of
as i said in 2009 looked at that and we said we've got a solution and the
solution consisted of two parts one of them was perhaps easier to implement and the other one was far less logical as
such but i want us to look into both base so first of all we said we are
going to change the architecture of such a system rather than having kimono less rather than hearing a single application
we're actually going to break it down into smaller much more manageable pieces which look like the desktop from Star
Wars but that's thousands and tens of thousands of Micro services and the term microservice
do and didn't even exist them but we broke it down into much smaller manageable pieces of code in each and
every of these pieces of code was a single function so rather than hearing a
single monolithic application we were able to focus in and have a single piece of data application to be developed
separately to have a very distinct atomic impotent output that receives and
function that it provides here in the overall system and then all of these components were able to communicate with
each other then we use the service oriented architecture and then later on
we we focused on using api's and HTTP was was obviously the way to go forward
and put a lot so poor rest on top of that matters little but ultimately we had multiple decoupled from each other
components that could communicate with each other to exchange information but
still remains independent from one another and that's great because it
actually allowed us to develop beach and every of these bits and pieces separately and therefore not not not
have a single monolithic pipeline but then as I said there was a less logical part of our journey that we needed to
consider as well and that was that we had to change our organization as well we had to change the culture in which we
thought and and operate it as such that's how we came up with a concept of
the two Pizza team so each and every these microservices was was then best
aunt and developed by a relatively small team somewhere between four and eight
developers and by the way I probably eat two pizzas myself so that's probably not a very good description of the size of
the team but let's say between four and eight people in a team that's to get up on the specific component of the system
the specific microservice and they're responsible in full for that service
that means they envision the function they then create the conceptual design
the logical design so how they communicate with the other micro services as well then
they do the physical design they develop the micro service they test it they
